item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded: A human chain formed across Bullart Street Sunday to move yarn from the former location to their new store at 621 N. Bullard St. Handing off yarn are Bill Blakemore, Susan Allen, Peggy Hutchinson, Randi Olsen, Awish Baetle, Mike Merchant and Susan Porter.

item.title: 20140202__SCS-L-SUPERBOWL-0203~p1
item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded: Sky Klaus - For the Sun-News Veterans and friends get ready to watch the Superbowl XLVIII Sunday at the VFW Post 3347 Sunday afternoon. Left to r: Leonard Pritkin, Ray Stryker, Connie Zawacki and David Tercero. A friendly rivalry broke out among veterans at the VFW Post before the big game got off the ground. About half the veterans who came to the Superbowl party fundraiser pulled for Denver while the other half pulled for Seattle. The WNMU Veteran's club, which held the Superbowl party for veterans Sunday, hoped to raise a couple hundred dollars to give to needy veterans and their families.

item.title: 20140202__SCS-L-SUPERBOWL-0203~p2
item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded: Sky Klaus - For the Sun-News Leonard Pritikin, 95, has been a member of VFW Post 3347 for 71 years. He enjoyed himself during Superbowl Sunday at the VFW Post, which was raising money for veterans and their families, sponsored by the WNMU Veterans club. Pritikin rooted for the Seatle Seahawks.

item.title: Another shot at birding starts Saturday in Silver City

SWNM Audubon is encouraging everyone to participate in the Audobon's bird count this weekend. To find out how to identify the birds, visit the Audubon's online bird guide at http://birds.audubon.org/birdid.

item.title: Group in Mimbres Valley plants butterfly bush to remember Alizandra Jasso

item.title: Senate committee kills bill to keep Gila River flowing free
The Wall Street Journal takes interest in Ft. Bayard
item.content:encoded: By Susan Dunlap - Sun-News Aaron Plump, who now lives in Arizona, was a Chief Petty Officer in the Navy for 22 years. Now Plump and his partner, McCurtis, dress as Buffalo Soldiers to tell a history that is often unknown. Plump and McCurtis visited Ft. Bayard and Ft. Bayard National Cemetery to pay their respects to the Buffalo Soldiers buried there and allow the Wall St. Journal to take photographs Wednesday.
item.excerpt:encoded: By Susan Dunlap - Sun-News Aaron Plump, who now lives in Arizona, was a Chief Petty Officer in the Navy for 22 years. Now Plump and his partner, McCurtis, dress as Buffalo Soldiers to tell a history that is often unknown. Plump and McCurtis visited Ft. Bayard and Ft. Bayard National Cemetery to pay their respects to the Buffalo Soldiers buried there and allow the Wall St. Journal to take photographs Wednesday.

item.title: Article, no frills
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
SILVER CITY >> Silver City Police Chief Ed Reynolds and Fire Chief Rudy Bencomo gave presentations at the town council meeting Wednesday about the importance of renewal of the public safety tax on March 4.

Originally approved by voters in 2004, the public safety tax imposes a one-eighth of 1 percent increase to the municipal infrastructure gross receipts tax in the town.

"It's not a new tax," Bencomo told the mayor and councilors. "It's a continuation of a tax implemented 10 years ago. And if it doesn't pass, we'll lose half a million dollars."

The tax was implemented in 2004 for the sole purpose of increasing public safety, but had a 10-year sunset requirement. So, voters must decide in the upcoming election if they want to continue it.

So far, the tax has paid for the salaries and benefits of four police officers and enabled the Police Department to purchase 17 patrol cars. In addition, the money has enabled the Fire Department to pay the salary and benefits of one fire fighter and purchase a ladder truck. The public safety tax has provided both departments with more than $3 million in the last 10 years.

Bencomo said that without the money the tax provides, the Silver City Fire Department will lose the fire fighter whose salary is provided by the tax. Bencomo stressed that the Fire Department seeks grant money wherever it can. He mentioned the nearly $60,000 NM State Fire grant the Fire Department received in 2013 to replace bunker gear and the increase in grass and structure fires in the area since 2010.

Advertisement

Reynolds stressed how frugal the Silver City Police Department has been in recent years and how hard the maintenance department has worked to keep the police fleet on the road. Reynolds gave a slide show demonstrating that the Police Department has two 1998 cars with more than 140,000 miles on them. The department has six 2001 vehicles with more than 142,000 miles on them. Reynolds said that according to national standards, a police vehicle is considered outdated once it reaches 75,000 miles. The department currently has 16 such vehicles.

"In 2005 a fully-equipped unit was approximately $26,000," Reynolds said. "Now the cost is about $30,000."

He also said the computers police officers use need to be replaced. Maintenance costs have soared due to the age of the department's fleet. And he hopes to move the department into using silent dispatch with new computers. He also said the men and women who join the city's police force are staying, on average, longer than they used to.

"It was three years," Reynolds said. "Now they're tending to stay with the department for about eight years, which is a good thing."

Reynolds stressed that if the public safety tax is approved, the city will be able to continue to see the level of service the city's police force already provides. The tax will continue to pay for the salaries and benefits of three Silver City police officers plus enable the department to invest in new patrol cars and equipment.

The councilors and the mayor expressed support for the public safety tax.

"If this tax fails, there'll be a new council and they'll be in a budget dilemma," Councilor Mike Morones said. "Cuts will have to be made somewhere."

Councilor Cynthia Ann Bettison agreed.

"There are other things that may have to be cut if this tax doesn't pass," Bettison said. "To have that peace of mind that we have fire and police and they have the equipment they need, to me it's a worthwhile tax and I hope we continue it. Otherwise, there'll be difficult decisions ahead."

Mayor James Marshall said that though he is stepping down as mayor after the March 4 election, the issue is still an important one to him as a Silver City resident.

"You can't tell a 911 caller, I'm sorry your house is on fire, we don't have the money to send you a truck," Marshall said. "I really don't have a dog in this fight other than that I'm a resident and will remain one after I'm no longer mayor. The tax isn't much, but it's impact is huge."

The town council voted in December on the ordinance that will allow the public safety tax to go before voters in March. This discussion of the public safety tax at Wednesday evening's council meeting allowed the public to hear about the tax.

In other business, the council approved an award bid of $340,373 to Diamond Construction for Blackhawk Road gravity sewer improvements and the council approved the list of names of the March 4 election workers.

"We owe these volunteers a big, big thank you," Marshall said before the council adjourned. "They ensure everyone gets a shot at voting."

Susan Dunlap can be reached at 575-538-5893 ext. 5803.

item.title: Terms of Use
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Article, large lead photo (i.e. featured image)
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Yada Yada Yarn stopped traffic for about an hour Sunday on Bullard St. to move to their new location at 621 N. Bullard St.

The effort began at noon and a line of knitters stood in the street as they handed baskets of yarn across a human chain to move the goods into their new storefront, now located at the corner of Bullard and Seventh Street next door to Alotta Gelotta. Yada Yada Yarn replaces the t-shirt printing shop. Cars were rerouted by the knitters until the old store stood empty.

item.title: Article with sidebar
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
SILVER CITY >> A unanimous decision Jan. 8 by the Water Quality Control Commission (WQCC) to maintain the so-called Copper Rule will allow Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc. to pollute ground water within a nine-square-mile area of the Tyrone Mine, according to Bruce Frederick, staff attorney with the New Mexico Environmental Law Center.

"The Copper Rule makes a bad situation worse," Frederick said.

The Copper Rules was passed last year to amend the Water Quality Control Act of 1977, which prohibits groundwater pollution beyond water quality standards. For more than 30 years, this has kept New Mexico's ground water relatively safe to drink. That could soon change, advocates said.

"The whole state's water is at risk," conservationist group Amigos Bravos Projects Director Rachel Conn said. "Since the Copper Rule's been adopted, the dairy industry and other industries want to have the same ability to change ground water standards."

The mining and dairy industries began lobbying the New Mexico Legislature a few years ago to revise the rules, according to Conn. Under the Water Quality Control Act, in order to pollute the ground water, each company had to apply for a variance — a lengthy process with no certainty of success. In addition, every industry had to adhere to the same set of regulations, Conn said. The mining and dairy industries wanted industry-specific regulations and they wanted to streamline the permitting process.

Advertisement

The industry got what it wanted last year when the Copper Rule was adopted. A request to stay the rule was rejected last month.

Eric Kinneberg, external communications director for Freeport-McMoRan, praised the decision to maintain the Copper Rule, and contended it is more stringent that what was previously in place.

"Freeport-McMoRan is pleased that the WQCC unanimously denied the request to delay the implementation of the Copper Rules," Kinneberg said through an emailed statement. "The WQCC cleared the way for the New Mexico Environment Department to renew the existing discharge permits. We are prepared to implement the Copper Rules' more stringent water protection requirements and appreciate the predictability and consistency the new rules represent for potential expanded operations."

Kinneberg denied conservationists' claims that the Copper Rule will allow for greater pollution.

"The Copper Rules were crafted by the New Mexico Environment Department with input from an advisory committee that considered the views of other government agencies, academics, environmental groups, scientific experts and industry," he said. "The process allowed all viewpoints to be considered and the Environment Department ultimately balanced these differing viewpoints and carefully considered the scientific and technical evidence supplied by the participants in crafting the rule. The Copper Rules establish detailed construction, design, monitoring, and closure requirements for new mining facilities as well as for the expansion of existing facilities, which were not specified by previous regulations or in discharge permits. As a result, the new rules replace an unpredictable system of permitting with consistent, enforceable measures that are expected to reduce impacts to groundwater at all New Mexico copper mining facilities."

Conn agreed that the group originally formed in 2012 was well balanced, with experts on both sides. But that group was drastically changed before the final rule was adopted, she said.

"We were really pleasantly surprised," Conn said. "The advisory committee of NMED staff and experts recommended rules that were a step forward."

But according to Conn, the situation changed while the new rules were still being drafted.

"The rules were changed and gutted by political appointees in NMED," Conn said. "It became vastly different."

In April 2013 Ryan Flynn was appointed by Gov. Susana Martinez as the new secretary of NMED, while the Copper Rule was still being drafted. At the time of his appointment, Flynn was acting as legal counsel for NMED. According to the Santa Fe New Mexican, before joining NMED as general legal counsel, Flynn previously worked for Modrall Sperling Law Firm, which represented Freeport before the WQCC, NMED and the courts.

Jim Winchester, communications director for the NMED & the Energy, Minerals & Natural Resources Department, disagreed with these allegations. In an emailed statement, he said, "Groups opposing the new Copper Rules continue to mislead the public using the same false, inaccurate talking points. Secretary Ryan Flynn proudly worked for several years at Modrall Sperling before joining the New Mexico Environment Department in January of 2011. While at Modrall Sperling, Secretary Flynn never worked on any cases representing Freeport-McMoran. Likewise, he chose to voluntarily recuse himself from any cases involving Modrall Sperling for his first year at the New Mexico Environment Department. Any suggestion that his former employment influenced his role in working with a consortium of regulators, academics and industry groups to come up with new Copper Rules is entirely false. The fact of the matter is that the newly adopted rules are the most environmentally protective rules for the copper mining industry in the country."

The 12-member WQCC board heard the final draft of the Copper Rule in September 2013.

"The WQCC has become completely politicized," Conn said. "They serve at the pleasure of the governor."

Winchester also disagreed with this allegation.

"From the perspective of NMED, any suggestion that the Water Quality Commission did not fairly deliberate on the adoption of the new rule or stay motion is completely false," he said. "The Commission listened and considered testimony from environmental experts, academics, industry representatives, environmental advocacy groups for several weeks before adopting the new rules. The new rules are over 40 pages long and provide greater protection for the state's ground water resources than the prior system, which allowed extensive contamination at mine sites around the state. Opponents of the new rules are seeking to defend a broken system that was already ruled illegal by the New Mexico Court of Appeals."

But according to Conn, the one dissenting vote on the WQCC, Doug Bland, who voted against the Copper Rule, resigned from the committee a month after the rules were voted for in September.

"Doug Bland no longer serves, but he was the commissioner who knew the most about mining. He was the former head of the mining minerals department," Conn said.

Frederick said conservationist groups had no hope of the WQCC overturning the rule it had just voted for, but to take the matter to the NM Court of Appeals, they had no choice but to go back to the WQCC first to apply for a motion to stay the rule.

"Now we're free to file the same motion to stay the Copper Rule in the Court of Appeals," Frederick said. "We're confidant the courts are an unbiased decision maker."

However, the judicial process will take two to three years, he said.

"This is the kind of pollution that lasts forever, the source is there forever," Frederick said. "Hundreds of years of perpetual pollution."

Freeport has 17 of 25 permits that are up for the repermitting process, according to Allyson Siwik, executive director of Gila Resources Information Project.

"This represents a rollback in how the state manages ground water," Siwik said of the permitting process.

Those 17 permits will be reviewed under the new Copper Rule.

"The Copper Rule allows pollution," Frederick said. "It legitimizes all the pollution that's already there."

According to Conn, the Copper Rule allows so-called sacrifice zones under certain areas. Ground water pollution is now allowed as long as Freeport pumps in more ground water to keep the polluted ground water contained.

"This will lead to perpetual pumping," Conn said.

Once the pumped ground water is brought into contact with the polluted ground water, the water that is pumped becomes polluted, too.

"This is bad in terms of how it effects the water supply, in terms of both supply and quality," Frederick said. "It's a race to the bottom, all those straws sucking from the same source, now the mine will be a huge straw. In an arid state, polluting thousands of acre-feet of good fresh water, there's a better way to do it."

According to Frederick, there is another issue at stake. The Copper Rule allows for something called financial assurance for the mining industry.

"If they go bankrupt, the state can take over," Frederick said.

According to Frederick, the Tyrone mine is expected to be depleted of mineral deposits within a couple of decades. This could cause the mine to shut down permanently.

"When the reserves end, there's no reason for them to exist any further," Frederick said. "They're a profit-driving force."

If the state is forced to take over the cleanup, that means taxpayers will ultimately get handed the bill.

"It really is impossible to clean that up, once it's been polluted," Frederick said. "All you can do is just contain it. But instead of doing it with walls and dams, they're doing it with pumps."

Susan Dunlap can be reached at 575-538-5893 ext. 5803.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
1984: Macintosh 128K

Price: $2,495

CPU speed: 8 MHz

The first, inspired by Lisa, with an all-in-one design that includes built-in monitor, 3.5” disk drive and a mouse. It was unveiled by Jobs Jan. 24, 1984, at Flint Center in Cupertino.

1993: Macintosh Color Classic

Price: $1,390

CPU speed: 16 MHz

First Macintosh with a built-in color display — but the last with the iconic box shape of the classic Mac.

1998: iMac

Price: $1,299

CPU speed: 233 MHz

Back in charge at Apple, Steve Jobs began streamlining Apple’s bloated product lines. He recharged the Mac faithful with the colorful and bullet-shaped iMac, the machine destined to become the digital hub for iPhoto, iTunes and the rest of our iLives.

2002: iMac G4

Price: $1,299 (15-inch)

CPU speed: 700/800 MHz

The first major design overhaul of the iMac, the new computer replaced bulky CRT screens with flat-panel monitors.

2005: iMac

Price: $1,199 (20-inch)

CPU speed: 2.4 GHz

Introduced in 2004, with a smaller footprint than previous models, it was upgraded in 2005 by a switch from IBM/Motorola’s Power PC chip to Intel chips.

Price: $1,299 (21.5-inch)

CPU speed: 2.7 GHz

Apple continues to improve screen resolution and boost processor speeds in the line that launched 30 years ago with the boxy Macintosh.

Sources: Apple, San Jose Mercury News archive

item.title: Article, sub-category, two photos
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Veterans and friends get ready to watch the Superbowl XLVIII Sunday at the VFW Post 3347 Sunday afternoon. Left to r: Leonard Pritkin, Ray Stryker, Connie Zawacki and David Tercero. [caption id="attachment_20" align="alignright" width="199"] Sky Klaus - For the Sun-News Leonard Pritikin, 95, has been a member of VFW Post 3347 for 71 years. He enjoyed himself during Superbowl Sunday at the VFW Post, which was raising money for veterans and their families, sponsored by the WNMU Veterans club. Pritikin rooted for the Seatle Seahawks.[/caption] A friendly rivalry broke out among veterans at the VFW Post before the big game got off the ground. About half the veterans who came to the Superbowl party fundraiser pulled for Denver while the other half pulled for Seattle. The WNMU Veteran's club, which held the Superbowl party for veterans Sunday, hoped to raise a couple hundred dollars to give to needy veterans and their families.
